awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Collaborative Proposal: Novel approaches to model travel behavior and sustainability impacts of e-bike use
awd_abstract_narration:
1706939 (Cherry)/ 1706695 (MacAuthur). Electric bicycles (e-bikes) are bicycles with a small battery-powered electric motor to assist the rider. Over 150 million e-bikes have been sold in Europe and Asia in the past ten years--in China's case, truly transformative transportation. This is the world's largest adoption of an alternative fuel vehicle. E-bikes are becoming more important in North America. However, there is little empirical evidence on the behavior of e-bike users and environmental sustainability impacts. The investigator team will refine and deploy a research study, using a combination of emerging hardware and software capabilities, to collect behavioral data from e-bike riders. The collected data will then be used to evaluate how large shifts in e-bike use will affect sustainability. The research in this GOALI project is enabled by an industry partner (Bosch). 

The first objective of this research is to refine an instrumentation system (physical hardware and a mobile device application) tailored for e-bike users. This system includes a mix of onboard hardware and smartphone software to collect a host of data on energy and other vehicle telematics. The data collected by the instrumentation and mobile application will be sent to a platform with little to no input required by the user. Using that data, the second objective is to assess the riding behavior of e-bike users and the performance of e-bikes in meeting travel needs. The research team will conduct an empirical study, starting with at least 150-200 participants for one year. This collaboration with industry partners will collect vehicle telematics and rider behavior metrics with an aim toward modeling net travel changes between modes (mode shift and vehicle kilometers traveled). This objective will identify how e-bike use behaviors differ from relatively well known incumbent modes. The third objective is to investigate the life-cycle environmental impacts of e-bike ownership and use, relying on the Department of Energy's GREET LCA model. Coupling the behavioral models with LCA models will provide a methodologically novel assessment of the impact of this new mode. This study will inform local and state policy and planning efforts related to the growth of e-bikes and their influence on environmental policy goals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Electric bikes (e-bikes) have rapidly grown in popularity as an accessible form of transportation that reduces barriers to cycling by limiting fatigue, reducing terrain barriers, and improving access to more parts of the transportation system. E-bikes are the most energy efficient mode of motorized transportation that exists, owing to efficient electric drive systems, low speeds, and low weight. Most of the energy to propel an e-bike moves the rider, rather than the vehicle. Most e-bikes require some rider input (pedaling) to activate the motor. Increasingly sophisticated e-bikes provide a seamless rider experience where the motor complements the riders pedaling. Recent e-bike models have begun to integrate sophisticated user interfaces and control systems.

E-bikes have always sold more units per year than electric cars and in 2021 more than one million e-bikes were sold. Policy makers continue to aim to understand how e-bikes can contribute to a sustainable transportation system. In the past year, legislation across the country has been proposed to incentivize e-bikes as a component of low-carbon transportation plans.

E-bikes straddle recreational and utility uses and until recently there was little understanding on how e-bike riders use their vehicles and, importantly, if e-bike riders reduce car trips with enough frequency to classify them as low-carbon transportation solutions. Self-reported results from surveys of e-bike users found that e-bikes do indeed replace a substantial amount of car trips, but those self-reported results are prone to bias. This work aimed to track e-bike trips from a rolling sample of e-bike users over the span of 12-18 months to identify use patterns over time. We worked with Bosch eBike Systems to develop a small instrumentation sensor, recruit and track riders, and identify the sustainability implications of their use. Specifically:

1) We developed a low energy Bluetooth dongle to attach to the Bosch computer that would be enabled when the e-bike was in use. We developed an iPhone and Android smartphone app that would communicate with the dongle and passively collect trip-level characteristics of e-bike users when they were riding their e-bike. The data included GPS traces and accelerometer data from the phone. The app would notify the user after each trip to label the trip purpose and the mode substitution.

2) We deployed the dongles to 38 riders over a two-year period. Each subject was recruited among Bosch e-bike riders and the logged data provided a comprehensive and rich dataset of all types and durations of trips for those users. Unfortunately, our data collection period spanned the entire early phase of COVID-19 so our data was tainted by the travel pattern changes of the pandemic. However, we still were able to demonstrate the methods and collect interesting data.

3) We did not require users to label all trips and developed novel machine learning approaches to classify trips by trip purpose and mode substitution patterns. This allows us to create a comprehensive dataset of all trips and apply sustainability models to understand the mode substitution patterns. Our algorithms neared 90% matching accuracy.

We found that e-bikes do substitute a substantial amount of car trips with e-bike trips. In early surveys, we found that e-bikes trips substitute about 2/3 of car trips (and Vehicle Miles Traveled). However, we found that during early COVID-19 months (April 2020-August 2020), commute trips reduced to practically zero and slowly recovered through early July 2021, when commute trips as a portion of all trips increased again. The majority of trips became recreational trips, which naturally do not replace car trips. 

Our entry and exit surveys confirm much of the findings of the disaggregate trip data collected over time. About half (47%) of all trips replaced car trips, confirming that e-bikes are a contributor toward reducing vehicle miles traveled and associated greenhouse gas emissions. It also shows that high-level self-reported survey questions, accompanied with a travel diary, can provide a relatively robust estimate of reduced vehicle miles traveled.

Despite the challenging circumstances associated with measuring transportation demand across a disruptive era in our history, we were able to gather a rich dataset that will be useful toward improving understanding how, when, where, and why people use e-bikes. This study provided educational opportunities to a diverse group of student ranging from high-school students, undergraduates, Masters and PhD students spanning civil engineering, computer science, electrical engineering, and city and regional planning. This work also meaningfully engaged with industry members and provides a stepping stone for future data analytics that is now becoming native to e-bike (and other micromobility manufacturer) platforms. Future work will leverage these emerging datasets to expand our sample to a broader sector of the e-bike market with a larger sample. Moreover, this work has been useful to policymakers, being quoted in rational for e-bike incentive programs to improve mobility and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
